variant.question: If the centre of gravity is near the forward limit, the aeroplane will:

options.text: require elevator trim, which will result in an increase in fuel consumption.
tend to over rotate during take-off.
benefit from reduced drag due to the decrease in angle of attack.
require less power for a given airspeed.

variant.question: The operator can add (1) ___ to the CG limits, to be (2) ___.
During take-off you notice that, for a given elevator input, the aeroplane rotates much more rapidly than expected. This is an indication that:

options.text: the centre of gravity may be towards the aft limit.
the centre of pressure is aft of the centre of gravity.
the centre of gravity is too far forward.

variant.question: If the centre of gravity is outside the forward limit in level and forward flight, the drag

options.text: decreases, and the fuel consumption decreases.

variant.question: Using the load and trim sheet, which of the following is the correct value for the index at a Dry Operating Mass (DOM) of 35 000 kg with a CG at 14% MAC?
For a medium range twin jet aircraft with a CG located at 18% MAC at 62 000 kg gross mass, determine the stabilizer trim units required for a take-off flap setting of 15°

Refer to figure or CAP 696 file 4.4. 
 For the MRJT1 with a CG at 19% MAC , Flaps 15°, what is the stabiliser trim setting for take-off?

Given Item         
Index    Mass DOI/DOM   54.0   39 000 kg
Passenger load  -2.21   10 715 kg
Cargo load   1.95   3 355 kg
Take-off fuel 11.84    8 900 kg
Find the approximate CG position as % MAC for the take-off
 The indexes are supposed to be in decimal form i.e 540 -> 54.0, -221 -> -2.21, 1953 -> 1.95, 1848 -> 11.84
The interval between 2 fleet mass evaluations must not exceed

Refer to Annex. Given the following indexes and masses, determine the take-off CG position as % MAC. - Dry operating index and mass: 50.0 and 35000 kg - Passenger load index and mass: -1.56 and 11508 kg - Cargo load index and mass: 1.45 and 1248 kg - Take-off fuel index and mass: 10.94 and 7800 kg
The fuel index:

options.text: is used to calculate the correct position of the CG due to different locations of the fuel tanks.
is a standard value given by EASA and can be used for different types of aircraft.
is the difference between the zero fuel mass index and the DOI.
is only used for aeroplanes with wing tip tanks.

variant.question:
Refer to figure 031-60.
Given:

- Weight: 110 800 kg
- MAC: 31.6 %

From the given values and information given by the attached sheet, find the dry operating index if an additional pilot (85 kg) will join the flight in zone E.

Refer to figure 031-60.
Given:

- Mass: 112 600 kg
- MAC: 30.7 %

From the given values and information given by the attached sheet, find the dry operating index if an additional pilot (75 kg) will join the flight in zone G.

An aeroplane, with its CG limits from 638 inches to 658 inches aft of the datum, should have been loaded so as to give a calculated Take-Off Mass of 64 200 kg and the CG located at 640 inches aft of the datum, with 750 kg loaded into the front cargo hold and 500 kg into the rear cargo hold. Unfortunately, the ground staff incorrectly loaded all the cargo into the forward cargo hold. If the distance between the cargo holds is 517 inches, is the aeroplane's CG within limits?

options.text: No, it is out of the forward limit.
No, it is out of the rear limit.
Yes, it moves rearwards but is within limits.

variant.question: When you are finished loading your aircraft, you find that the CG is 2 inches forward of the CG limit. The CG limits are between 12 and 16% MAC. MAC is 40 inches and LEMAC is 200 inches aft of datum. What can you do to get the CG within limits if the total mass is 62,800 kg?

options.text: All of the following is correct.
Add 1670.21 kg to the aft compartment 280 inches aft of datum.
Remove 679.65 kg from the forward cargo hold 20 inches aft of datum.
Move 483.07 kg from the forward cargo hold 20 inches aft of datum to the aft cargo hold 280 inches aft of datum.

variant.question: A pilot is preparing a flight with one passenger, assuming that the passenger will sit on the front seat. The mass of the passenger is 170 lb and the station of the front row is at 85 inches aft of the datum. The pilot calculates a take-off mass of 4100 lb with a CG at 94 inches aft of the datum. The CG limits are from 86 inches aft of the datum to 95 inches aft of the datum. When the passenger arrives, he asks the pilot if he can sit on the rear seat, which is located at 158 inches aft of the datum. The pilot calculates the new CG and the result is:

options.text: No, it is not possible; the CG is out of the rear limit.
Yes, it is possible; the CG is still within the limits.
Yes, it is possible, because the CG moves rearwards.
No, it is not possible; the CG is out of the forward limit.

DOI/DOM: 54.0 39 000 KG

Cargo Load: 1.95 3 355 kg
Take off fuel: 11.84 8 900 kg
Find the approximate CG position as % MAC for the take-off:

Refer to figure. 
 For take-off performance purposes, you need to establish a CG position at take-off at 798 inches aft of the datum. Given the following information, which one of the two boxes must be moved and into which hold?Current CG position: 780 inches aft of the datum. 
 Actual Take-off mass: 48 700 lb. 
 Box X is located 1185 inches aft of the datum, in hold 5. 
 Box Z is located 180 inches aft of the datum, in hold 1. 
 Both boxes have the same mass of 880 lb.Consider the fuel consumption from engine start to take-off negligible.

options.text: Box Z must be moved to hold 5.
Box X must be moved to hold 4.
Box Z must be moved to hold 4.
Box X must be moved to hold 1.

Forward limit: 71.4 in; aft limit: 88.4 in

variant.question:
During the pre-flight, the pilot assumed that the only passenger weighing 170 lb would sit at the front-row seat (located 85 inches aft of datum). The calculations gave a Take-Off Mass of 4100 lb and a take-off CG located at 94 inches aft of datum.
When the passenger arrives, he/she sits at the rear seat, located 158 inches aft of datum. The CG limits are from 86 inches to 95 inches aft of datum. Determine if the new CG within limits:

options.text: No, it is out of the rear limit.
Yes, as the CG moves rearwards.
No, it is out of the forward limit.
Yes, it is within the CG envelope.

 Block Fuel: 600 lb

 Disregard Start-up and Taxi Fuel values
What is the purpose of the trim sheet in Mass and Balance?

options.text: a graphical reasoning to determine the CG position of operational masses.
a graphical method to determine various operational masses.
an arithmetical reasoning to determine the CG position of operational masses.
an arithmetical reasoning to determine various operational masses.

The aft CG limit is located at 2.57 m. The datum is located in front of the aircraft. Is it allowed to fly under otherwise identical conditions if a pilot weights 10 kg less than given in the table? - MASS (kg) ARM (m) MOMENT (kgm) - Empty Mass 410 2.74 1 123.6 - Pilot 80 2 160 - Fuel 90 2.3 207

options.text: Yes, the new centre of gravity is now located more forward within the allowable range.
Yes, the new centre of gravity is located slightly forward of the aft limit, thus still within the allowable range.
No, the new centre of gravity is located slightly aft of the aft limit, thus outside the allowable range.
Yes, the reduced mass can only have a positive effect

variant.question:
Is it allowed to fly under otherwise identical conditions if a pilot weights 10 kg less than given in the table? **Assume that the aft CG limit is located at 2.57 m and the datum is in front of the aircraft.**

-   

  <td>MASS (kg) ARM (m) MOMENT (kgm)
  </tr>
  <tr> Empty Mass 410 2.74 1 123.6
  </tr>
  <tr> Pilot 80 2 160
  </tr>
  <tr> Fuel 90 2.3 207

options.text: No, the new centre of gravity is located slightly aft of the aft limit, thus outside the allowable range.
Yes, the new centre of gravity is located slightly forward of the aft limit, thus still within the allowable range.
Yes, the new centre of gravity is now located more forward within the allowable range.
Yes, reducing the mass will have a positive effect.

Refer to figure. 
 Using the data given in the Load & Trim sheet, determine which of the following gives the correct values for the Zero Fuel Mass and position of the centre of gravity (% MAC) at that mass.

Prior to every Commercial Air Transport flight of a large aircraft, the Operator uses an electronic or a paper format trim sheet to determine the Centre of Gravity of the actual Zero Fuel Mass, Take-Off Mass and Landing Mass. What is the purpose of the trim sheet?

options.text: This is to ensure that the CGs are within the certified envelope, and is achieved by using the index method.
This is done by referring to the stations of various fuselage sectors defined in mass and balance documentation.
This is done by computing the balance arm of the actual operational masses and the results are given in metres or inches.
This is to check that they are below the limits published in the Aircraft flight Manual, and is achieved by calculating the moments.

Yes, the new centre of gravity is now located more forward within the allowable range.
No, the new centre of gravity is located 1 cm aft of the aft limit, thus outside the allowable range.
Yes, the reduced mass can only have a positive effect
